awd_titl_txt: CRII: CHS: Improving Data Exploration by Mining Analyst Behavior
awd_abstract_narration:
Data analysts must explore increasingly large amounts of information. A variety of tools to visualize, filter, and model data help make it more manageable. Yet they bring with them a chance of errors of interpretation, omission, or cognitive bias. This project develops techniques for making data analysis tools more resistant to such errors.  The team will record and store logs of the processes many different analysts use to explore a variety of datasets. From these logs of analyst behavior, the team will create models that identify both potentially advantageous and risky working strategies. They will use this model, along with tools designed to detect biases, to build new data analysis tools. The new tools will shape the presentation of data to users and suggest exploration choices to help counter errors and biases.  For example, if past successful analysts, when faced with a similar set of data, performed a particular sequence of operations, the tool might suggest that the current user pursue similar procedures.  The tools and work will be deployed publicly, benefiting individuals who may be less familiar with data science.

The ultimate goal of this research program is to construct data analytics technology that learns from experts' work in order to improve the experience of novice data scientists.  In this project, the team will build a dataset of analyst behavior using crowdsourcing platforms.  To identify commonalities among many different analysts and datasets, they will develop a vocabulary (or set of abstractions) of analysis actions grounded in existing literature on analytics tool design. These actions will be encapsulated as states in a probabilistic graphical model of the sequence of actions taken during analysis.  The team will explore how different behavior abstractions influence the fitting of the probabilistic model. The team will create algorithms to match new analyst sessions to the existing models and identify potential targets for intervention (or coaching) points during the data exploration. The project will incorporate these interventions into existing data analysis tools as a proof of concept, exploring in laboratory studies how individuals respond to different strategies of intervention. In addition to developing specific models and tools around data analytics workflow, this project sets up a broader research agenda of mining interaction logs for deeper insights into analyst cognition and working strategies.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

por.por_cntn:
As data sources grow, analysts must explore increasingly large amounts of information. Because humans remain an integral part of the data analysis process, a variety of tools visualize, filter, and model data to make it more manageable. Yet, these simplified displays of data bring with them a chance of errors of interpretation, omission, or cognitive bias. In this project, the research team gathered information and developed new techniques for making data analysis tools more rigorous and resistant to such errors.

First, the team recorded logs which outline the step-by-step process many different data analysts used to explore a variety of datasets. The team developed a novel technique called Tessera for breaking apart these complicated logs into individual segments of goal-directed behavior. In other words, Tessera helps to split the complex stream of interactions a user has with the data tool (such as mouse clicks, picking options, or typing) into pieces which correspond to specific goals or interests. The team used this log analysis tool to understand how different individuals went about exploring data.

Second, the team developed a new system called Silva which helped analysts to reduce bias in their own datasets using the insights they learned from the logs they collected. In comparison to other comparable platforms, Silva helped users to explore the data for bias issues more deeply in a controlled study. The design of Silva can help to inform the design of future tools that help users inspect data. Development of Silva also led to another storehouse of log data, this time collected as users used the Silva tool and other comparable data de-biasing tools.

Third, using all the log data collected as well as additional controlled studies, the team examined how individuals went about using data tools on a fine-grained level. Observing analysts in action, the team discovered how the design of different data tools can shape how users reason about their data, and might cause them to over- or under-explore certain parts of the data. In a publication of these findings, the team describes three different patterns of data exploration that different tool designs encourage through the features they provide to users.

Finally, the team?s algorithms and logs have been integrated into publicly accessible toolkits and ongoing work related to large language models (such as ChatGPT) and whether they can accurately and usefully provide help to data analysts.

Articles describing each of these four outcomes have been released at academic conference venues. The findings from this project will help to inform the development of new data analytics systems, and an understanding of how users explore data (as illustrated by the log data collected) will help designers to zero in on the right features to deploy to support new data analysts. It is important to understand the ways in which tools are actually used by analysts, as they shape the kinds of findings and conclusions drawn from the data. Findings from this project, more broadly, will inform how society makes use of data tools and, in turn, how analysis of data affects society in the future.

 


Last Modified: 08/03/2023
Modified by: Jeffrey M Rzeszotarski

Images (1 of )
  • The Silva interface helps analysts to explore relationships between data variables (show in the colored network diagram) in order to identify issues of bias.
    Jing Nathan Yan, Ziwei Gu, Jeffrey Rzeszotarski
    Copyrighted
    Jeffrey M Rzeszotarski
    Silva exploratory interface
  • The way in which a data de-biasing tools is designed shapes the behavior of analysts. Three different systems show remarkably different behavior on the part of analysts, as outlined using flow diagrams.
    Jing Nathan Yan, Ziwei Gu, Jeffrey Rzeszotarski
    Copyrighted
    Jeffrey M Rzeszotarski
    Sensemaking models for three user interfaces
